Fair Federated Learning via Bounded Group Loss

Shengyuan Hu
CMU
shengyua@andrew.cmu.edu    Zhiwei Steven Wu
CMU
zstevenwu@cmu.edu    Virginia Smith
CMU
smithv@cmu.edu
Abstract

Fair prediction across protected groups is an important constraint for many federated learning applications. However, prior work studying group fair federated learning lacks formal convergence or fairness guarantees. In this work we propose a general framework for provably fair federated learning. In particular, we explore and extend the notion of Bounded Group Loss as a theoretically-grounded approach for group fairness. Using this setup, we propose a scalable federated optimization method that optimizes the empirical risk under a number of group fairness constraints. We provide convergence guarantees for the method as well as fairness guarantees for the resulting solution. Empirically, we evaluate our method across common benchmarks from fair ML and federated learning, showing that it can provide both fairer and more accurate predictions than baseline approaches.

1 Introduction

Group fairness aims to mitigate unfair biases against certain protected demographic groups (e.g. race, gender, age) in the use of machine learning. Many methods have been proposed to incorporate group fairness constraints in centralized settings [e.g., 17, 34, 1, 15]. However, there is a lack of work studying these approaches in the context of federated learning (FL), a training paradigm where a model is fit to data generated by a set of disparate data silos, such as a network of remote devices or collection of organizations [25, 19, 21]. Mirroring concerns around fairness in non-federated settings, many FL applications similarly require performing fair prediction across protected groups. Unfortunately, as we show in Figure 1, naively applying existing approaches to each client in a federated network in isolation may be inaccurate due to heterogeneity across clients—failing to produce a fair model across the entire population [37].

Several recent works have considered addressing this issue by exploring specific forms of group fairness in FL [e.g., 7, 37, 28, 8, 13, 29]. Despite promising empirical performance, these prior works lack formal guarantees surrounding the resulting fairness of the solutions (Section 2), which is problematic as it is unclear how the methods may perform in real-world FL deployments.

In this work we provide a formulation and method for group fair FL that can provably satisfy global fairness constraints. Common group fairness notions that aim to achieve equal prediction quality between any two protected groups (e.g., Demographic Parity, Equal Opportunity [17]) are difficult to provably satisfy while simultaneously finding a model with high utility. Instead, we consider a different fairness notion known as Bounded Group Loss (BGL) [2], which aims to promote worst group’s performance, to capture these common group fairness criteria. As we show, a benefit of this approach is that in addition to having practical advantages in terms of fairness-utility trade-offs (Section 5), it maintains smoothness and convexity properties that can equip our solver with favorable theoretical guarantees.

Based on our group fairness formulation, we then provide a scalable method (PFFL) to solve the proposed objectives via federated saddle point optimization. Theoretically, we provide convergence guarantees for the method as well as fairness and generalization guarantees for the resulting solutions. Empirically, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach on common benchmarks from fair machine learning and federated learning. We summarize our main contributions below:

  • •

    We propose a novel fair federated learning framework for a range of group fairness notions. Our framework models the fair FL problem as a saddle point optimization problem and leverages variations of Bounded Group Loss [2] to capture common forms of group fairness. We also extend BGL to consider a new fairness notion called Conditional Bounded Group Loss (CBGL), which may be of independent interest and utility in non-federated settings.

  • •

    We propose a scalable federated optimization method for our group fair FL framework. We provide a regret bound analysis for our method under convex ML objectives to demonstrate formal convergence guarantees. Further, we provide fairness and generalization guarantees on the model for a variety of fairness notions.

  • •

    Finally, we evaluate our method on common benchmarks used in fair machine learning and federated learning. In all settings, we find that our method can significantly improve model fairness compared to baselines without sacrificing model accuracy. Additionally, even though we do not directly optimize classical group fairness constraints (e.g., Demographic Parity, Equal Opportunity), we find that our method can still provide comparable/better fairness-utility trade-offs relative to existing approaches when evaluated on these metrics.

2 Background and Related Work

Fair Machine Learning. Algorithmic fairness in machine learning aims to identify and correct bias in the learning process. Common approaches for obtaining fairness include pre-processing methods that rectify the features or raw data to enhance fairness [36, 15, 6]; post-processing methods that revise the prediction score for a trained model [17, 14, 26]; and in-processing methods that directly modify the training objective/solver to produce a fair predictor [1, 2, 34, 35, 32]. Most existing methods in fair ML rely on using a centralized dataset to train and evaluate the model. As shown in Figure 1, in the federated setting where data is privately distributed across different data silos, directly applying these methods locally only ensures fairness for each silo rather than the entire population. Developing effective and efficient techniques for fair FL is thus an important area of study.

Fair Federated Learning. In FL, definitions of fairness may take many forms. A commonly studied notion of fairness is representation parity [18], whose application in FL requires the model’s performance across all clients to have small variance [27, 20, 12, 33, 22]. In this work we instead focus on notions of group fairness, in which every data point in the federated network belongs to some (possibly) protected group, and we aim to find a model that doesn’t introduce bias towards any group.

Recent works have proposed various objectives for group fairness in federated learning. Zeng et al. [37] proposes a bi-level optimization objective that minimizes the difference between each group’s loss while finding an optimal global model. Similarly, several works propose using a constrained optimization problem that aims to find the best model subject to an upper bound on the group loss difference [7, 29, 13, 8]. Different from these approaches, our method focuses on a fairness constraint based on upperbounding the loss of each group with a constant rather than the loss difference between any two groups. More closely related to our work, Papadaki et al. [28] weighs the empirical loss given each group by a trainable vector 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda} and finds the best model for the worst case 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda}. Though similar to our method for ζ=0𝜁0\zeta=0, this approach fails to achieve both strong utility and fairness performance under non-convex loss functions (see Section 5). Zhang et al. [38] also propose a similar objective to learn a model with unified fairness. Among these works, Zeng et al. [37] and Cui et al. [8] also provide simplified convergence and fairness guarantees for their method. However, these works lack formal analyses around the convergence for arbitrary convex loss functions as well as the behavior of the fairness constraint over the true data distribution. Ours is the first work we are aware to provide such guarantees in the context of group fair federated learning.

3 Fair Federated Learning via Bounded Group Loss

In this section we first formalize the group fair federated learning problem and a fairness-aware objective solving this problem (Section 3.1). We then provide several examples of group fairness based on the notion of BGL and show how to incorporate them into our framework (Section 3.2).

3.1 Setup: Group Fair Federated Learning

Many applications of FL require treatment of data belonging to protected groups (e.g., race, gender, age). This is particularly common in applications of cross-silo FL, where we may wish to produce a model that fairly treats individuals from various demographic groups across a collection of data silos (e.g. hospitals, schools, financial institutions) [7, 31, 8].

FL Setup.

Following standard federated learning scenarios [25], we consider a network with K𝐾K different clients. Fairness via Constrained Optimization.

When a centralized dataset is available, a standard approach to learn a model that incorporates fairness criteria is to solve a constrained optimization problem where one tries to find the best model subject to some fairness notion [4, 2]. Following this formulation, we formalize a similar learning problem in the federated setting, solving:

minh∈ℋ⁡F​(h)subject to ​𝐑​(h)≤𝜻,subscriptℎℋ𝐹ℎsubject to 𝐑ℎ𝜻\begin{array}[]{cc}\min_{h\in\mathcal{H}}F(h)&\text{subject to }\mathbf{R}(h)\leq\boldsymbol{\zeta},\end{array} (3)

where 𝐑​(h),𝜻∈ℝZ𝐑ℎ𝜻superscriptℝ𝑍\mathbf{R}(h),\boldsymbol{\zeta}\in\mathbb{R}^{Z} encodes the constraint set on hℎh. For instance, the z𝑧z-th constraint could be written as 𝐑z​(h)≤ζzsubscript𝐑𝑧ℎsubscript𝜁𝑧\mathbf{R}_{z}(h)\leq\zeta_{z} where ζzsubscript𝜁𝑧\zeta_{z} is a fixed constant. This formulation is commonly used to satisfy group fairness notions such as equal opportunity, equalized odds [17], and minimax group fairness [9].

To solve the constrained optimization problem 3, a common method is to use Lagrangian multipliers. In particular, let 𝝀∈ℝ+Z𝝀superscriptsubscriptℝ𝑍\boldsymbol{\lambda}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{Z} be a dual variable and assume 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda} has ∥⋅∥1\|\cdot\|_{1} at most B𝐵B. The magnitude of B𝐵B could be viewed as the regularization strength for the constraint term. Objective (3) can then be converted into the following saddle point optimization problem:

minw⁡max𝝀∈ℝ+Z,‖𝝀‖1≤B⁡G​(w;𝝀)=β​F​(w)+𝝀T​𝐫​(w),subscript𝑤subscriptformulae-sequence𝝀superscriptsubscriptℝ𝑍subscriptnorm𝝀1𝐵𝐺𝑤𝝀𝛽𝐹𝑤superscript𝝀𝑇𝐫𝑤\min_{w}\max_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{Z},\|\boldsymbol{\lambda}\|_{1}\leq B}G(w;\boldsymbol{\lambda})=\beta F(w)+\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{T}\mathbf{r}(w)\,, (Main Objective)

where the q𝑞q-th index of 𝐫𝐫\mathbf{r} encodes the q𝑞q-th constraint from 𝐑𝐑\mathbf{R} (i.e. 𝐫q​(w):=𝐑q​(w)−ζqassignsubscript𝐫𝑞𝑤subscript𝐑𝑞𝑤subscript𝜁𝑞\mathbf{r}_{q}(w):=\mathbf{R}_{q}(w)-\zeta_{q}) and β𝛽\beta is a fixed constant. In other words, the objective finds the best model under the scenario where the fairness constraint is most violated (i.e., the regularization term is maximized).

There are two steps needed in order to provide meaningful utility and fairness guarantees for the model found by solving Main Objective: (1) showing that it is possible to recover a solution close to the ‘optimal’ solution, (2) providing an upper bound for both the risk (F​(w)𝐹𝑤F(w)) and the fairness constraint (𝐫​(w)𝐫𝑤\mathbf{r}(w)) given this solution. To formally define what an ‘optimal’ solution is, in this work we aim to identify constraints that satisfy the following key assumption:

Assumption 0 (Convexity of G𝐺G).

Assume that G​(w;𝛌)𝐺𝑤𝛌G(w;\boldsymbol{\lambda}) is convex in w𝑤w for any fixed 𝛌𝛌\boldsymbol{\lambda}.

Remark.

In particular, since G𝐺G is linear in 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda}, given a fixed w0subscript𝑤0w_{0}, we can find a solution to the problem max𝝀⁡G​(w0;𝝀)subscript𝝀𝐺subscript𝑤0𝝀\max_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}G(w_{0};\boldsymbol{\lambda}), denoted as 𝝀∗superscript𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{*}, i.e. G​(w0;𝝀∗)≥G​(w0;𝝀)𝐺subscript𝑤0superscript𝝀𝐺subscript𝑤0𝝀G(w_{0};\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{*})\geq G(w_{0};\boldsymbol{\lambda}) for all 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda}. When G𝐺G is convex in w𝑤w, we can argue that given a fixed 𝝀0subscript𝝀0\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{0}, there exists w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} that satisfies w∗=arg​minw⁡G​(w;𝝀0)superscript𝑤subscriptargmin𝑤𝐺𝑤subscript𝝀0w^{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{w}G(w;\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{0}), i.e. G​(w∗;𝝀0)≤G​(w;𝝀0)𝐺superscript𝑤subscript𝝀0𝐺𝑤subscript𝝀0G(w^{*};\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{0})\leq G(w;\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{0}) for all w𝑤w. Therefore, (w∗,𝝀∗)superscript𝑤superscript𝝀(w^{*},\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{*}) is a saddle point of G​(⋅;⋅)𝐺⋅⋅G(\cdot;\cdot), which is denoted as the optimal solution in our setting.

3.2 Formulating Fair FL: Bounded Group Loss and Variants

Many prior works in fair federated learning consider instantiating 𝐑​(h)𝐑ℎ\mathbf{R}(h) in (3) as a constraint that bounds the difference between any two groups’ losses, a common technique used to enforce group fairness notions such as equalized odds and demographic parity [e.g., 37, 7, 8]. Unfortunately, this results in G​(w;𝝀)𝐺𝑤𝝀G(w;\boldsymbol{\lambda}) becoming nonconvex in w𝑤w, thus violating our Assumption 0. This nonconvexity is problematic as it increases the likelihood that a solver will find a local minima that either does not satisfy the fairness constraint or achieves poor utility. Instead of enforcing equity between the prediction quality of any two groups, in this work we explore using a constraint based on Bounded Group Loss (BGL) [2] which promotes worst group’s prediction quality and propose new variants that can retain convexity assumptions while satisfying meaningful fairness notions. In particular, we explore three instantiations of group fairness constraints 𝐑​(h)𝐑ℎ\mathbf{R}(h) that satisfy Assumption 0 below.

Instantiation 1 (Bounded Group Loss).

We begin by considering fairness via the Bounded Group Loss (defined below), which was originally proposed by Agarwal et al. [2]. Different from applying Bounded Group Loss in a centralized setting, BGL in the context of federated learning requires that for any group a∈A𝑎𝐴a\in A, the average loss for all data belonging to group a𝑎a is below a certain threshold. As we discuss in Section 4 this (along with general constraints of FL such as communication) necessitates the development of novel solvers and analyses for the objective.

Definition 1 (Agarwal et al. [2]).

A classifier hℎh satisfies Bounded Group Loss (BGL) at level ζ𝜁\zeta under distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} if for all a∈A𝑎𝐴a\in A, we have 𝔼​[l​(h​(x),y)|A=a]≤ζ𝔼delimited-[]conditional𝑙ℎ𝑥𝑦𝐴𝑎𝜁\mathbb{E}\left[l(h(x),y)|A=a\right]\leq\zeta .

In practice, we could define empirical bounded group loss constraint at level ζ𝜁\zeta under the empirical distribution 𝒟^=1K​∑k=1K𝒟^k^𝒟1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript^𝒟𝑘\widehat{\mathcal{D}}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\widehat{\mathcal{D}}_{k} to be

𝐫a​(h):=∑k=1K𝐫a,k​(h)=∑k=1K(1/ma​∑ak,i=al​(h​(xk,i),yk,i)−ζ/K)≤0.assignsubscript𝐫𝑎ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐫𝑎𝑘ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝑚𝑎subscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑖𝑎𝑙ℎsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖𝜁𝐾0\displaystyle\mathbf{r}_{a}(h):=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbf{r}_{a,k}(h)=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(1/m_{a}\sum_{a_{k,i}=a}l(h(x_{k,i}),y_{k,i})-\zeta/K\right)\leq 0\,.

Benefits of BGL.

BGL ensures that the prediction quality on any group reaches a certain threshold. Compared to standard loss parity constraints that aim to equalize the losses across all protected groups (e.g. overall accuracy equity [10]), BGL has two main advantages. First, G​(w;𝝀)𝐺𝑤𝝀G(w;\boldsymbol{\lambda}) preserves convexity in w𝑤w, as long as the loss function l𝑙l itself is convex. In contrast, loss parity constraints are generally non-convex even if l𝑙l is convex. Second, when the prediction difficulties are uneven across groups, loss parity may force an unnecessary drop of accuracy on some groups just to equalize all losses [2]. In contrast, the criterion of BGL can avoid such undesirable effects.

Instantiation 2 (Conditional Bounded Group Loss).

In some applications one needs a stronger fairness notion beyond ensuring that no group’s loss is too large. For example, in the scenario of binary classification, a commonly used fairness requirement is equalized true positive rate or false positive rate [17]. In the context of optimization for arbitrary loss functions, a natural substitute is equalized true / false positive loss. In other words, any group’s loss conditioned on positively / negatively labeled data should be equalized. Therefore, similar to BGL, we propose a novel fairness definition known as Conditional Bounded Group Loss (CBGL) defined below:

Definition 2.

A classifier hℎh satisfies Conditional Bounded Group Loss (CBGL) for y∈Y𝑦𝑌y\in Y at level ζysubscript𝜁𝑦\zeta_{y} under distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} if for all a∈A𝑎𝐴a\in A, we have 𝔼​[l​(h​(x),y)|A=a,Y=y]≤ζy𝔼delimited-[]formulae-sequenceconditional𝑙ℎ𝑥𝑦𝐴𝑎𝑌𝑦subscript𝜁𝑦\mathbb{E}\left[l(h(x),y)|A=a,Y=y\right]\leq\zeta_{y}.

In practice, we could define empirical Conditional Bounded Group Loss constraint at level [ζy]y∈Ysubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜁𝑦𝑦𝑌[\zeta_{y}]_{y\in Y} under 𝒟^^𝒟\widehat{\mathcal{D}} to be

𝐫a,y​(h):=∑k=1K𝐫(a,y),k​(h)=∑k=1K(1/ma,y​∑ak,i=a,yk,i=yl​(h​(xk,i),yk,i)−ζy/K)≤0.assignsubscript𝐫𝑎𝑦ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐫𝑎𝑦𝑘ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝑚𝑎𝑦subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑎𝑘𝑖𝑎subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖𝑦𝑙ℎsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖subscript𝜁𝑦𝐾0\mathbf{r}_{a,y}(h):=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathbf{r}_{(a,y),k}(h)=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\left(1/m_{a,y}\sum_{a_{k,i}=a,y_{k,i}=y}l(h(x_{k,i}),y_{k,i})-\zeta_{y}/K\right)\leq 0\,.

Note that satisfying CBGL for all Y𝑌Y is a strictly harder problem than satisfying BGL alone. In fact, we can show that a classifier that satisfies CBGL at level [ζy]y∈Ysubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜁𝑦𝑦𝑌[\zeta_{y}]_{y\in Y} also satisfies BGL at level 𝔼y∼ρa​[ζy]subscript𝔼similar-to𝑦subscript𝜌𝑎delimited-[]subscript𝜁𝑦\mathbb{E}_{y\sim\rho_{a}}[\zeta_{y}] where ρasubscript𝜌𝑎\rho_{a} be the probability density of labels for all data from group a𝑎a.

Relationship between CBGL and Equalized Odds.

For binary classification tasks in centralized settings, a common fairness notion is Equalized Odds (EO) [17], which requires the True/False Positive Rate to be equal for all groups. Our CBGL definition can be viewed as a relaxation of EO. Consider a binary classification example where Y={0,1}𝑌01Y=\{0,1\}. Let the loss function l𝑙l be the 0-1 loss. CBGL requires classifier hℎh to satisfy Pr[h(x)=y|Y=y0,A=a]≤ζy0\text{Pr}[h(x)=y|Y={y_{0}},A=a]\leq\zeta_{y_{0}} for all a∈A𝑎𝐴a\in A and y0∈Ysubscript𝑦0𝑌y_{0}\in Y. EO requires Pr[h(x)=y|Y=y0,A=a]\text{Pr}[h(x)=y|Y={y_{0}},A=a] to be the same for all a∈A𝑎𝐴a\in A given a fixed y0subscript𝑦0y_{0}, which may not be feasible if the hypothesis class ℋℋ\mathcal{H} is not rich enough. Instead of requiring equity of each group’s TPR/FPR, CBGL only imposes an upper bound for each group’s TPR/FPR. Similar to the comparison between BGL and loss parity, CBGL offers more flexibility than EO since it does not force an artificial increase on FPR or FNR when a prediction task on one of the protected groups is much harder. In addition, for applications where logistic regression or DNNs are used (e.g., CV, NLP), it is uncommon to use the 0-1 loss in the objective. Thus, CBGL can provide a relaxed notion of fairness for more general loss functions whose level of fairness can be flexibly tuned.

Instantiation 3 (MinMax Fairness).

Recently Papadaki et al. [28] proposed a framework called FedMinMax by solving an agnostic fair federated learning framework where the weight is applied to empirical risk conditioned on each group. Note that using BGL as the fairness constraint, our framework could reduce to FedMinMax as a special case by setting β=0,B=1formulae-sequence𝛽0𝐵1\beta=0,B=1 and ζ=0𝜁0\zeta=0.

Definition 3.

Use the same definition of 𝐫a​(h)subscript𝐫𝑎ℎ\mathbf{r}_{a}(h) as we had in Instantiation 1. FedMinMax [28] aims to solve for the following objective: minh⁡max𝛌∈ℝ+|A|,‖𝛌‖1=1​∑a∈A𝛌a​𝐫a​(h)subscriptℎsubscriptformulae-sequence𝛌superscriptsubscriptℝ𝐴subscriptnorm𝛌11subscript𝑎𝐴subscript𝛌𝑎subscript𝐫𝑎ℎ\min_{h}\max_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}\in\mathbb{R}_{+}^{|A|},\|\boldsymbol{\lambda}\|_{1}=1}\sum_{a\in A}\boldsymbol{\lambda}_{a}\mathbf{r}_{a}(h).

Note that a key property of FedMinMax is the constant ζ𝜁\zeta used to upper bound the per group loss is set to 0. From a constrained optimization view, the only feasible solution that satisfies all fairness constraints for this problem is a model with perfect utility performance since requiring all losses to be smaller than 0 is equivalent to having all of them to be exactly 0. Such a property limits the ability to provide fairness guarantees for FedMinMax. Fixing B𝐵B and ζ𝜁\zeta also limits its empirical performance on the relation between fairness and utility, as we will show later in Appendix E.

4 Provably Fair Federated Learning

In this section, we first propose Provably Fair Federated Learning (PFFL), a scalable solver for Main Objective, presented in Algorithm 1. We provide formal convergence guarantees for the method in Section 4.2. Given the solution found by PFFL, in Section 4.3 we then demonstrate the fairness guarantee for different examples of fairness notions defined in Section 3 (BGL, CBGL).

4.1 Algorithm

To find a saddle point for Main Objective, we follow the scheme from Freund and Schapire [16] and summarize our solver for fair FL in Algorithm 1. Our algorithm is based off of FedAvg [25], a common scalable approach in federated learning. Intuitively, the method alternates between two steps:

  • (1) given a fixed 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda}, optimize our regularized objective F​(w)+𝝀T​𝐫​(w)𝐹𝑤superscript𝝀𝑇𝐫𝑤F(w)+\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{T}\mathbf{r}(w) over w𝑤w;

  • (2) given a fixed w𝑤w, optimize the fairness violation term 𝝀T​𝐫​(w)superscript𝝀𝑇𝐫𝑤\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{T}\mathbf{r}(w) over 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda}.

While Agarwal et al. [2] also follows a similar recipe to ensure BGL, our method needs to overcome additional challenges in the federated settings. In particular, the method in Agarwal et al. [2] optimizes w𝑤w by performing exact best response, which is in general in feasible when data for distributed data sets. Our method overcomes this challenge by applying a gradient-descent-ascent style optimization process that utilizes the output of a FL learning algorithm as an approximation for the best response. In Algorithm 1, we provide an example in which the first step is achieved by using FedAvg to solve minw⁡F​(w)+𝝀T​𝐫​(w)subscript𝑤𝐹𝑤superscript𝝀𝑇𝐫𝑤\min_{w}F(w)+\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{T}\mathbf{r}(w) (line 4-12). Note that solving this objective does not require the FedAvg solver; any algorithm that learns a global model in FL could be used to find a certain w𝑤w given 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda}. After we obtain a global model from a federated training round, we use exponentiated gradient descent to update 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda}, following Alg 2 in Agarwal et al. [2]. This completes one minimax optimization round. At the end of training, we calculate and return the average iterate as the fair global model.

Note that the ultimate goal to solve for Main Objective is to find a w𝑤w such that it minimizes the empirical risk subject to 𝐫​(w)≤0𝐫𝑤0\mathbf{r}(w)\leq 0. Therefore, at the end of training, our algorithm checks whether the resulting model w¯¯𝑤\bar{w} violates the fairness guarantee by at most some constant error M+2​νB𝑀2𝜈𝐵\frac{M+2\nu}{B} where M𝑀M is the upper bound for the empirical risk and ν𝜈\nu is the upper bound provided in Equation 5 (line 16-20). We will show in the Lemma 1 that this is always true when there exists a solution w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} for Problem 3. However, it is also worth noting that the Problem 3 does not always have a solution w∗superscript𝑤w^{*}. For example when we set ζ=0𝜁0\zeta=0, requiring 𝐫​(w)≤0𝐫𝑤0\mathbf{r}(w)\leq 0 is equivalent to requiring the empirical risk given any group a∈A𝑎𝐴a\in A is non positive, which is only feasible when the loss is 0 for every data in the dataset. In this case, our algorithm will simply output null if the fairness guarantee is violated by an error larger than M+2​νB𝑀2𝜈𝐵\frac{M+2\nu}{B}.

4.2 Convergence guarantee

Different from Agarwal et al. [2], while our algorithm handles arbitrary convex losses in federated setting by replacing the best response with the FedAvg output, we want to show that after running finitely many rounds, how close our solution is to the actual best response. In this section, we provide a no regret bound style analysis for our PFFL algorithm. To formally measure the the distance between the solution found by our algorithm and the optimal solution, we introduce ν𝜈\nu-approximate saddle point as a generalization of saddle point (See Remark in Section 3.1) defined below:

Definition 4.

(w^,𝝀^)^𝑤^𝝀(\widehat{w},\widehat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}) is a ν𝜈\nu-approximate saddle point of G𝐺G if

G​(w^,𝝀^)≤G​(w,𝝀^)+νfor all ​wG​(w^,𝝀^)≥G​(w^,𝝀)−νfor all ​𝝀𝐺^𝑤^𝝀𝐺𝑤^𝝀𝜈for all 𝑤𝐺^𝑤^𝝀𝐺^𝑤𝝀𝜈for all 𝝀\begin{array}[]{cc}G(\widehat{w},\widehat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}})\leq G(w,\widehat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}})+\nu&\text{for all }w\\ G(\widehat{w},\widehat{\boldsymbol{\lambda}})\geq G(\widehat{w},\boldsymbol{\lambda})-\nu&\text{for all }\boldsymbol{\lambda}\end{array} (4)

As an example, the optimal solution (w∗,𝝀∗)superscript𝑤superscript𝝀(w^{*},\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{*}) is a 0-approximate saddle point of G𝐺G. To show convergence, we first introduce some basic assumptions below:

Assumption 1.

Let fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} be μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex and L𝐿L-smooth for all k=1,⋯,K𝑘1⋯𝐾k=1,\cdots,K.

Assumption 2.

Assume the stochastic gradient of fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} has bounded variance: 𝔼​[‖∇fi​(wtk;ξtk)−∇fk​(wtk)‖2]≤σk2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝑘∇subscript𝑓𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑡𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘2\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla f_{i}(w_{t}^{k};\xi_{t}^{k})-\nabla f_{k}(w_{t}^{k})\|^{2}]\leq\sigma_{k}^{2} for all k=1,⋯,K𝑘1⋯𝐾k=1,\cdots,K.

Assumption 3.

Assume the stochastic gradient of fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k} is uniformly bounded: 𝔼​[‖∇fk​(wtk;ξtk)‖2]≤G2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑡𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝑘2superscript𝐺2\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla f_{k}(w_{t}^{k};\xi_{t}^{k})\|^{2}]\leq G^{2} for all k=1,⋯,K𝑘1⋯𝐾k=1,\cdots,K.

These are common assumptions used when proving the convergence for FedAvg [e.g., 23]. Now we present our main theorem of convergence:

Theorem 1 (Informal Convergence Guarantee).

Let Assumption 1-3 hold. Define κ=Lμ𝜅𝐿𝜇\kappa=\frac{L}{\mu}, γ=max⁡{8​κ,J}𝛾8𝜅𝐽\gamma=\max\{8\kappa,J\} and step size ηQ=2(β+B)​μ​(γ+t)subscript𝜂𝑄2𝛽𝐵𝜇𝛾𝑡\eta_{Q}=\frac{2}{(\beta+B)\mu(\gamma+t)}, and assume ‖𝐫‖∞≤ρsubscriptnorm𝐫𝜌\|\mathbf{r}\|_{\infty}\leq\rho. Letting w¯=1E​T​∑t=1E​Twt¯𝑤1𝐸𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝐸𝑇superscript𝑤𝑡\bar{w}=\frac{1}{ET}\sum_{t=1}^{ET}w^{t}, 𝛌¯=1E​T​∑t=1E​T𝛌t¯𝛌1𝐸𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝐸𝑇superscript𝛌𝑡\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}=\frac{1}{ET}\sum_{t=1}^{ET}\boldsymbol{\lambda}^{t}, we have:

max𝝀⁡G​(w¯;𝝀)−minw⁡G​(w;𝝀¯)≤1T​∑t=1Tκγ+t−1​C+B​log⁡(Z+1)ηθ​E​T+ηθ​ρ2​B,subscript𝝀𝐺¯𝑤𝝀subscript𝑤𝐺𝑤¯𝝀1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇𝜅𝛾𝑡1𝐶𝐵𝑍1subscript𝜂𝜃𝐸𝑇subscript𝜂𝜃superscript𝜌2𝐵\max_{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}G(\bar{w};\boldsymbol{\lambda})-\min_{w}G(w;\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda}})\leq{\color[rgb]{0.58431372549,0.15294117647,0.90980392156}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58431372549,0.15294117647,0.90980392156}\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{\kappa}{\gamma+t-1}C}+{\color[rgb]{0.67843137254,0.41568627451,0.09019607843}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.67843137254,0.41568627451,0.09019607843}\frac{B\log(Z+1)}{\eta_{\theta}ET}+\eta_{\theta}\rho^{2}B}\,,\vspace{-.1in} (5)

where C𝐶C is a constant.

The upper bound in Equation 5 consists of two parts: (1) the error for the FedAvg process to obtain w¯¯𝑤\bar{w} which is a term of order 𝒪​(log⁡T/T)𝒪𝑇𝑇\mathcal{O}(\log T/T); (2) the error for the Exponentiated Gradient Ascent process to obtain 𝝀¯¯𝝀\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda}} which converges to a noise ball given a fixed ηθsubscript𝜂𝜃\eta_{\theta}. Following Theorem 1, we could express the solution of Algorithm 1 as a ν𝜈\nu-approximate saddle point of G𝐺G by picking appropriate ηθsubscript𝜂𝜃\eta_{\theta} and T𝑇T:

Corollary 2.

Let ηθ=ν2​ρ2​Bsubscript𝜂𝜃𝜈2superscript𝜌2𝐵\eta_{\theta}=\frac{\nu}{2\rho^{2}B} and T≥1ν​(γ+1)−2​κ​𝒞​(4​ρ2​B2​log⁡(Z+1)​(γ+1)ν​E+2​κ​𝒞​(γ−1))𝑇1𝜈𝛾12𝜅𝒞4superscript𝜌2superscript𝐵2𝑍1𝛾1𝜈𝐸2𝜅𝒞𝛾1T\geq\frac{1}{\nu(\gamma+1)-2\kappa\mathcal{C}}\left(\frac{4\rho^{2}B^{2}\log(Z+1)(\gamma+1)}{\nu E}+2\kappa\mathcal{C}(\gamma-1)\right), then (w¯,𝛌¯)¯𝑤¯𝛌(\bar{w},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}) is a ν𝜈\nu-approximate saddle point of G𝐺G.

We provide detailed proofs for both Theorem 1 and Corollary 2 in Appendix B. Different from the setting in prior FedAvg analyses [e.g., 23], in our case the outer minimization problem changes as 𝝀𝝀\boldsymbol{\lambda} gets updated. Therefore, our analysis necessitates considering a more general scenario where the objective function could change over time.

4.3 Fairness guarantee

In the previous section, we demonstrated that our Algorithm 1 could converge and find a ν𝜈\nu-approximate saddle point of the objective G𝐺G. In this section, we further motivate why we care about finding a ν𝜈\nu-approximate saddle point. The ultimate goal for our algorithm is to: (1) learn a model that produces fair predictions on training data, and (2) more importantly, produces fair predictions on test data, i.e., data from federated clients not seen during training.

Before presenting the formal fairness and generalization guarantees, we state the following additional assumption, which is a common assumption for showing the generalization guarantee using the Rademacher complexity generalizations bound [27].

Assumption 4.

Let ℱℱ\mathcal{F} and F𝐹F be upper bounded by constant M𝑀M.

We first show the fairness guarantee on the training data.

Lemma 1 (Empirical Fairness Guarantee).

Assume there exists w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} satisfies 𝐫​(w∗)≤𝟎Z𝐫superscript𝑤subscript0𝑍\mathbf{r}(w^{*})\leq\mathbf{0}_{Z}, we have

maxj⁡𝐫j​(w¯)+≤M+2​νB.subscript𝑗subscript𝐫𝑗subscript¯𝑤𝑀2𝜈𝐵\max_{j}\mathbf{r}_{j}(\bar{w})_{+}\leq\frac{M+2\nu}{B}. (6)

Lemma 1 characterizes the upper bound for the worst fairness constraint evaluated on the training data. Given a fixed ν𝜈\nu, one could increase B𝐵B to obtain a stronger fairness guarantee, i.e. a smaller upper bound. Combining this with Corollary 2, it can be seen that when B𝐵B is large, additional exponentiated gradient ascent rounds are required to achieve stronger fairness.

Next we formalize the fairness guarantee for the entire true data distribution. Define the true data distribution to be 𝒟=1K​∑k=1K𝒟k𝒟1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\mathcal{D}_{k}. We would like to formalize how well our model is evaluated on the true distribution 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} as well as how well the fairness constraint is satisfied under 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. This result is presented below in Theorem 3.

Theorem 3 (Full Fairness and Generalization Guarantee).

Let Assumption 1-4 holds and (w¯,𝛌¯)¯𝑤¯𝛌(\bar{w},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}) a ν𝜈\nu-approximate saddle point of G𝐺G. Then with probability 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, either there doesn’t exist solution for Problem 3 and Algorithm 1 returns null or Algorithm 1 returns w¯¯𝑤\bar{w} satisfies

ℱ​(w¯)≤ℱ​(w∗)+2​ν+4​ℜm​(ℋ)+2​MK​∑k=1K12​mk​log⁡(2/δ),𝔯j​(w¯)≤M+2​νB+G​e​n𝐫,jℱ¯𝑤ℱsuperscript𝑤2𝜈4subscriptℜ𝑚ℋ2𝑀𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾12subscript𝑚𝑘2𝛿subscript𝔯𝑗¯𝑤𝑀2𝜈𝐵𝐺𝑒subscript𝑛𝐫𝑗\begin{array}[]{c}\mathcal{F}(\bar{w})\leq\mathcal{F}(w^{*})+2\nu+4\mathfrak{R}_{m}(\mathcal{H})+\frac{2M}{K}\sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{2m_{k}}\log(2/\delta)},\\ \mathfrak{r}_{j}(\bar{w})\leq\frac{M+2\nu}{B}+Gen_{\mathbf{r},j}\end{array} (7)

where w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} is a solution for Problem 3 and G​e​n𝐫𝐺𝑒subscript𝑛𝐫Gen_{\mathbf{r}} is the generalization error.

The first part for Equation 7 characterizes how well our model performs over the true data distribution compared to the optimal solution. As number of clients K𝐾K increases, we achieve smaller generalization error. The second part for Equation 7 characterizes how well the fairness constraints are satisfied over the true data distribution. Note that the upper bound could be viewed as the sum of empirical fairness violation and a generalization error. Based on our fairness notions defined in Section 3.2, we demonstrate what generalization error is under different fairness constraints 𝐫𝐫\mathbf{r}.

Proposition 1 (𝐫𝐫\mathbf{r} encodes BGL at level ζ𝜁\zeta).

There are in total |A|𝐴|A| fairness constraints, one for each group. Define the weighted rademacher complexity for group a𝑎a as

ℜa​(ℋ)=𝔼Sk∼𝒟kmk,σ​[suph∈ℋ∑k=1K1ma​∑ak,i=aσk,i​l​(h​(xk,i),yk,i)]subscriptℜ𝑎ℋsubscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘𝜎delimited-[]subscriptsupremumℎℋsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝑚𝑎subscriptsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑖𝑎subscript𝜎𝑘𝑖𝑙ℎsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖\mathfrak{R}_{a}(\mathcal{H})=\mathbb{E}_{S_{k}\sim\mathcal{D}_{k}^{m_{k}},\sigma}\left[\sup_{h\in\mathcal{H}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{m_{a}}\sum_{a_{k,i}=a}\sigma_{k,i}l\left(h(x_{k,i}),y_{k,i}\right)\right]. In this scenario, we have:

G​e​n𝐫,a=2​ℜa​(ℋ)+Mma​K2​log⁡(2​|A|/δ).𝐺𝑒subscript𝑛𝐫𝑎2subscriptℜ𝑎ℋ𝑀subscript𝑚𝑎𝐾22𝐴𝛿Gen_{\mathbf{r},a}=2\mathfrak{R}_{a}(\mathcal{H})+\frac{M}{m_{a}}\sqrt{\frac{K}{2}\log(2|A|/\delta)}.

Note that the fairness constraint for group a𝑎a under true distribution in Equation 7 is upper bounded by 𝒪​(Kma)𝒪𝐾subscript𝑚𝑎\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\sqrt{K}}{m_{a}}\right). For any group a0subscript𝑎0a_{0} with sufficient data, i.e., ma0subscript𝑚subscript𝑎0m_{a_{0}} is large, the BGL constraint with respect to group a0subscript𝑎0a_{0} under 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} has a stronger formal fairness guarantee compared to any group with less data. It is also worth noting that this generalization error grows as the number of clients K𝐾K grows. Recall that the generalization error becomes smaller when K𝐾K grows; combing the two results together provides us a tradeoff between fairness notion of BGL and utility over the true data distribution in terms of K𝐾K.

Proposition 2 (𝐫𝐫\mathbf{r} encodes CBGL at level [ζy]y∈Ysubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝜁𝑦𝑦𝑌[\zeta_{y}]_{y\in Y}).

There are in total |A|​|Y|𝐴𝑌|A||Y| fairness constraints, one for each group and label. Define the weighted rademacher complexity for group a𝑎a conditioned on y𝑦y as ℜa,y​(ℋ)=𝔼Sk∼𝒟kmk,σ​[suph∈ℋ∑k=1K1ma,y​∑ak,i=a,yk,i=yσk,i​l​(h​(xk,i),y)]subscriptℜ𝑎𝑦ℋsubscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘𝜎delimited-[]subscriptsupremumℎℋsuperscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝑚𝑎𝑦subscriptformulae-sequencesubscript𝑎𝑘𝑖𝑎subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖𝑦subscript𝜎𝑘𝑖𝑙ℎsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖𝑦\mathfrak{R}_{a,y}(\mathcal{H})=\mathbb{E}_{S_{k}\sim\mathcal{D}_{k}^{m_{k}},\sigma}\left[\sup_{h\in\mathcal{H}}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{m_{a,y}}\sum_{a_{k,i}=a,y_{k,i}=y}\sigma_{k,i}l\left(h(x_{k,i}),y\right)\right] where ma,ysubscript𝑚𝑎𝑦m_{a,y} is the number of all examples from group a𝑎a with label y𝑦y. In this scenario, we have:

G​e​n𝐫,(a,y)=2​ℜa,y​(ℋ)+Mma,y​K2​log⁡(2​|A|​|Y|/δ).𝐺𝑒subscript𝑛𝐫𝑎𝑦2subscriptℜ𝑎𝑦ℋ𝑀subscript𝑚𝑎𝑦𝐾22𝐴𝑌𝛿Gen_{\mathbf{r},{(a,y)}}=2\mathfrak{R}_{a,y}(\mathcal{H})+\frac{M}{m_{a,y}}\sqrt{\frac{K}{2}\log(2|A||Y|/\delta)}.

Similar to Proposition 1, in order to achieve strong fairness guarantees for any specific constraint on the true data distribution, we need a sufficient number of samples associated with that constraint.

We provide details and proof for Theorem 3 in Appendix C. Different from the analysis performed in Agarwal et al. [2], we analyze the generalization behaviour in federated setting where we introduce the generalization bound as a function of number of clients K𝐾K. We then further formally demonstrate the tension between utility and fairness performance evaluated on the true data distribution induced by K𝐾K, which has not been studied previously to the best of our knowledge.

5 Experiments

We evaluate PFFL (Algorithm 1) empirically on ProPublica COMPAS, a dataset commonly studied in fair ML [3, 37]; the US-wide ACS PUMS data, a recent group fairness benchmark dataset [11]; and CelebA [5], a common federated learning dataset. We compare our method with training a vanilla FedAvg model in terms of both fairness and utility in Section 5.1, and explore performance relative to baselines that aim to enforce other fairness notions (Demographic Parity and Equal Opportunity) in Section 5.2.

Setup. For all experiments, we evaluate the accuracy and the empirical loss for each group on test data that belongs to all the silos of our fair federated learning solver. We consider COMPAS Recidivism prediction with gender as protected attribute, the ACS Employment task [11] with race as protected attribute, and CelebA [5] with gender as a protected attribute. To reflect the federated setting, we use heterogeneous data partitions to create data silos. ACS Employent is naturally partitioned into 50 states; COMPAS and CelebA are manually partitioned in a non-IID manner into a collection of data silos. A detailed description of datasets, models, and partition schemes can be found in Appendix A.

5.1 Fairness-Utility Trade-offs for Algorithm 1

We first explore how test error rate differs as a function maximum group loss using our Algorithm 1. To be consistent with our method and theoretical analysis, we exclude the protected attribute aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} for each data as a feature for learning the predictor. For each dataset, we evaluated PFFL with BGL; CBGL for Y=1𝑌1Y=1; and CBGL for Y=0𝑌0Y=0. For each method we evaluate, given fixed number of training iterations E𝐸E and T𝑇T, we finetune B𝐵B and ζ𝜁\zeta and evaluate both test error rate and test loss on each group. Given a certain test error rate, we select the hyperparameter pair (B,ζ)𝐵𝜁(B,\zeta) that yields the lowest maximum group loss. We show the relation between test accuracy vs. max group loss in Figure 2. In particular, we compare our fairness-aware FL methods with two baseline methods: vanilla FedAvg and FedAvg trained on loss weighted by groups. In FL, applying fair training locally at each data silo and aggregating the resulting model may not provide strong population-wide fairness guarantees with the same fairness definition [37]. Hence, we also explore the relationship between test accuracy and max group loss under local BGL and global BGL constraints.

On all datasets, there exists a natural tradeoff between error rate and the fairness constraint: when a model achieves stronger fairness (smaller max group loss), the model tends to have worse utility (higher error rate). However, in all scenarios, our method not only yields a model with significantly smaller maximum group loss than vanilla FedAvg, but also achieves higher test accuracy than the baseline FedAvg which is unaware of group fairness. Meanwhile, for all datasets and fairness metrics, as expected, PFFL with Global BGL achieves improved fairness-utility tradeoffs relative to PFFL with Local BGL. Therefore, our PFFL with Global fairness constraint framework yields a model where utility can coexist with fairness constraints relying on Bounded Group Loss.

5.2 BGL/CBGL evaluated on other fairness notions

Beyond BGL and CBGL, there are other fairness notions commonly used in the fair machine learning literature. For example, several works in group fair FL have proposed optimizing the difference between every two groups’ losses (possibly conditioned on the true label) with the aim of achieving Demographic Parity (or Equal Opportunity) [17, 7, 8, 37]. Formally, consider the case where the protected attribute set A={0,1}𝐴01A=\{0,1\}. Define ΔD​P=|Pr(h(X)=1|A=0)−Pr(h(X)=1|A=1)|\Delta_{DP}=\left|\text{Pr}(h(X)=1|A=0)-\text{Pr}(h(X)=1|A=1)\right| and ΔE​O=|Pr(h(X)=1|A=0,Y=1)−Pr(h(X)=1|A=1,Y=1)|\Delta_{EO}=\left|\text{Pr}(h(X)=1|A=0,Y=1)-\text{Pr}(h(X)=1|A=1,Y=1)\right|. These works aim to train a model such that we could achieve small ΔD​PsubscriptΔ𝐷𝑃\Delta_{DP} or small ΔE​OsubscriptΔ𝐸𝑂\Delta_{EO}, depending on the fairness constraint selected during optimization. As discussed in Section 3.2, CBGL could be viewed as a more general definition of Equal Opportunity and Equalized Odds. In this section, we compare our method with FedFB [37], FedFair [7], and FCFL [8], all of which aim to optimize ΔD​PsubscriptΔ𝐷𝑃\Delta_{DP} and ΔE​OsubscriptΔ𝐸𝑂\Delta_{EO}. We evaluate ΔD​PsubscriptΔ𝐷𝑃\Delta_{DP} and ΔE​OsubscriptΔ𝐸𝑂\Delta_{EO} for all approaches on COMPAS and ACS Employment, with results shown in Figure 3. Similar to Figure 2, we only show the points lying on the pareto frontier for our method. Although PFFL with BGL and CBGL was not directly designed for this fairness criteria (i.e., it does not directly enforce the loss or prediction parity of two groups’ losses to be close), we see that our method is still able to outperform training a FedAvg baseline, and in fact performs comparably or better than prior methods (which were designed for this setting).

6 Conclusions, Limitations, and Future Work

In this work, we propose a fair learning objective for federated settings via Bounded Group Loss. We then propose a scalable federated solver to find an approximate saddle point for the objective. Theoretically, we provide convergence and fairness guarantees for our method. Empirically, we show that our method can provide high accuracy and fairness simultaneously across tasks from fair ML and federated learning. In addition to strong empirical performance, ours is the first work we are aware of to provide formal convergence and fairness/generalization guarantees for group fair FL with general convex loss functions. In future work we are interested in investigating additional benefits that could be provided by using our framework, including applications in non-federated settings. Finally, similar to prior works in group fair FL, our method communicates additional parameters beyond standard non-fair FL (e.g., via FedAvg); studying and mitigating the privacy risks of such communications in the context of fair federated learning would be an interesting direction of future work.

Appendix A Datasets and Models

We summarize the details of the datasets and models we used in our empirical study in Table 1. Our experiments include both convex (Logistic Regression) and non-convex (CNN) loss objectives on both fairness (ACS Employment [11], COMPAS [3]) and federated learning (CelebA [24, 5]) benchmarks. Our model choices are common and also used in prior works for ACS Employment [11], CelebA [5], and COMPAS [3].

Proof for corollary 1.

Appendix C Proof for Theorem 3

We first introduce a few lemmas necessary for the proof of Theorem 3.

Let

ℜm​(ℋ)=𝔼Sk∼𝒟kmk,σ​[suph∈ℋ1K​∑k=1K1mk​∑i=1mkσk,i​l​(h​(xk,i),yk,i)]subscriptℜ𝑚ℋsubscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝑚𝑘𝜎delimited-[]subscriptsupremumℎℋ1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾1subscript𝑚𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑚𝑘subscript𝜎𝑘𝑖𝑙ℎsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖\mathfrak{R}_{m}(\mathcal{H})=\mathbb{E}_{S_{k}\sim\mathcal{D}_{k}^{m_{k}},\sigma}\left[\sup_{h\in\mathcal{H}}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{m_{k}}\sum_{i=1}^{m_{k}}\sigma_{k,i}l\left(h(x_{k,i}),y_{k,i}\right)\right]

then for any h∈ℋℎℋh\in\mathcal{H}, with probability 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, we have

Let (w¯,𝛌¯)¯𝑤¯𝛌(\bar{w},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}) is a ν𝜈\nu-approximate saddle point, then

where x+=max⁡{x,0}subscript𝑥𝑥0x_{+}=\max\{x,0\}.

For any w𝑤w such that 𝐫​(w)≤𝟎Z𝐫𝑤subscript0𝑍\mathbf{r}(w)\leq\mathbf{0}_{Z}, F​(w¯)≤F​(w)+2​ν𝐹¯𝑤𝐹𝑤2𝜈F(\bar{w})\leq F(w)+2\nu.

Proof for lemma 1.

Note that

F​(w¯)+B​maxz∈Z⁡𝐫z​(w¯)+−ν𝐹¯𝑤𝐵subscript𝑧𝑍subscript𝐫𝑧subscript¯𝑤𝜈\displaystyle F(\bar{w})+B\max_{z\in Z}\mathbf{r}_{z}(\bar{w})_{+}-\nu ≤F​(w¯)+𝝀¯T​𝐫​(w¯)absent𝐹¯𝑤superscript¯𝝀𝑇𝐫¯𝑤\displaystyle\leq F(\bar{w})+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}^{T}\mathbf{r}(\bar{w}) (36)
=G​(w¯,𝝀¯)absent𝐺¯𝑤¯𝝀\displaystyle=G(\bar{w},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}) (37)
≤minw⁡G​(w,𝝀¯)+νabsentsubscript𝑤𝐺𝑤¯𝝀𝜈\displaystyle\leq\min_{w}G(w,\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda}})+\nu (38)
≤G​(w∗,𝝀¯)+νabsent𝐺superscript𝑤¯𝝀𝜈\displaystyle\leq G(w^{*},\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda}})+\nu (39)
=F​(w∗)+𝝀¯T​𝐫​(w∗)+νabsent𝐹superscript𝑤superscript¯𝝀𝑇𝐫superscript𝑤𝜈\displaystyle=F(w^{*})+\bar{\boldsymbol{\lambda}}^{T}\mathbf{r}(w^{*})+\nu (40)
≤F​(w∗)+ν.absent𝐹superscript𝑤𝜈\displaystyle\leq F(w^{*})+\nu. (41)

Therefore, we have

F​(w¯)≤F​(w∗)+2​ν.𝐹¯𝑤𝐹superscript𝑤2𝜈F(\bar{w})\leq F(w^{*})+2\nu. (42)

Hence,

B​maxz∈Z⁡𝐫z​(w¯)+𝐵subscript𝑧𝑍subscript𝐫𝑧subscript¯𝑤\displaystyle B\max_{z\in Z}\mathbf{r}_{z}(\bar{w})_{+} ≤F​(w∗)−F​(w¯)+2​νabsent𝐹superscript𝑤𝐹¯𝑤2𝜈\displaystyle\leq F(w^{*})-F(\bar{w})+2\nu (43)
≤M+2​ν.absent𝑀2𝜈\displaystyle\leq M+2\nu. (44)

∎

Note that Lemma 1 tells us when there exists a solution for problem 3, the empirical fairness constraint violates by at most an error of M+2​νB𝑀2𝜈𝐵\frac{M+2\nu}{B}. In other words, this guarantees that our algorithm 1 always output a model when problem 3 has a solution.

Now we provide a proof of Theorem 3.

Proof for Theorem 3.

When there exists a solution to Problem 3: w∗superscript𝑤w^{*}, by Lemma 3, 1, we have with probability 1−δ/21𝛿21-\delta/2

ℱ​(w¯)ℱ¯𝑤\displaystyle\mathcal{F}(\bar{w}) ≤F​(w¯)+2​ℜm​(ℋ)+MK​∑k=1K12​mk​log⁡(2/δ)absent𝐹¯𝑤2subscriptℜ𝑚ℋ𝑀𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾12subscript𝑚𝑘2𝛿\displaystyle\leq F(\bar{w})+2\mathfrak{R}_{m}(\mathcal{H})+\frac{M}{K}\sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{2m_{k}}\log(2/\delta)} (45)
≤F​(w∗)+2​ν+2​ℜm​(ℋ)+MK​∑k=1K12​mk​log⁡(2​δ)absent𝐹superscript𝑤2𝜈2subscriptℜ𝑚ℋ𝑀𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾12subscript𝑚𝑘2𝛿\displaystyle\leq F(w^{*})+2\nu+2\mathfrak{R}_{m}(\mathcal{H})+\frac{M}{K}\sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{2m_{k}}\log(2\delta)} (46)
≤ℱ​(w∗)+2​ν+4​ℜm​(ℋ)+2​MK​∑k=1K12​mk​log⁡(2/δ).absentℱsuperscript𝑤2𝜈4subscriptℜ𝑚ℋ2𝑀𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾12subscript𝑚𝑘2𝛿\displaystyle\leq\mathcal{F}(w^{*})+2\nu+4\mathfrak{R}_{m}(\mathcal{H})+\frac{2M}{K}\sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{2m_{k}}\log(2/\delta)}. (47)

Combined with Lemma 6, 7, and 1, we have for all rjsubscript𝑟𝑗r_{j} that encodes a fairness constraint, with probability 1−δ/21𝛿21-\delta/2

𝔯j​(w¯)subscript𝔯𝑗¯𝑤\displaystyle\mathfrak{r}_{j}(\bar{w}) ≤𝐫j​(w¯)+G​e​nr,j​(δ/2)absentsubscript𝐫𝑗¯𝑤𝐺𝑒subscript𝑛𝑟𝑗𝛿2\displaystyle\leq\mathbf{r}_{j}(\bar{w})+Gen_{r,j}(\delta/2) (48)
≤M+2​νB++Genr,j(δ/2)\displaystyle\leq\frac{M+2\nu}{B}++Gen_{r,j}(\delta/2) (49)

Therefore, Theorem 3 holds with probability 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta in this case.

When there doesn’t exist a solution to problem 3, Algorithm 1 outputs w¯¯𝑤\bar{w} only when maxa∈A⁡𝐫a​(w¯)≤M+2​νBsubscript𝑎𝐴subscript𝐫𝑎¯𝑤𝑀2𝜈𝐵\max_{a\in A}\mathbf{r}_{a}(\bar{w})\leq\frac{M+2\nu}{B}. In certain scenarios, we are still able to obtain

𝔯a​(w¯)≤M+2​νB+G​e​nr,j​(δ/2)subscript𝔯𝑎¯𝑤𝑀2𝜈𝐵𝐺𝑒subscript𝑛𝑟𝑗𝛿2\displaystyle\mathfrak{r}_{a}(\bar{w})\leq\frac{M+2\nu}{B}+Gen_{r,j}(\delta/2) (50)

by applying Lemma 1. Since w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} doesn’t exist, the following holds vacuously:

ℱ​(w¯)≤ℱ​(w∗)+2​ν+4​ℜm​(ℋ)+2​MK​∑k=1K12​mk​log⁡(2/δ)ℱ¯𝑤ℱsuperscript𝑤2𝜈4subscriptℜ𝑚ℋ2𝑀𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾12subscript𝑚𝑘2𝛿\displaystyle\mathcal{F}(\bar{w})\leq\mathcal{F}(w^{*})+2\nu+4\mathfrak{R}_{m}(\mathcal{H})+\frac{2M}{K}\sqrt{\sum_{k=1}^{K}\frac{1}{2m_{k}}\log(2/\delta)} (51)

Therefore, Theorem 3 holds for both cases.

∎

Appendix D Hyperparameters

In order to get the fairest model given a certain test error rate, we apply random grid search over two key hyperparameters in our experiment: the strength of regularizer B𝐵B and the constant used to bound our fairness constraint (ζ𝜁\zeta when BGL is the fairness constraint and ζysubscript𝜁𝑦\zeta_{y} when CBGL conditioned on Y=y𝑌𝑦Y=y is the fairness constraint). For all our experiments w.r.t PFFL with BGL and PFFL with CBGL, we select B∈{0.1,0.5,1,5,10,100,200,500}𝐵0.10.51510100200500B\in\{0.1,0.5,1,5,10,100,200,500\}. Appendix E Comparison with FedMinMax [28]

As mentioned in Section 3.2, FedMinMax [28] can be viewed as a special case of our PFFL with BGL with fixed hyperparameters. However, different from our Algorithm 1, the original FedMinMax solver proposes to fix the FedAvg training epoch T=1𝑇1T=1 whereas our PFFL proposes to training enough number of FedAvg rounds. We compare PFFL with FedMinMax in Figure 4. Similar to Figure 2, we only plot the pareto frontier of our method. Although PFFL with BGL could reduce to FedMinMax, fixing hyperparameters (e.g. β,B,ζ,T𝛽𝐵𝜁𝑇\beta,B,\zeta,T) limits FedMinMax’s flexibility to trade off between fairness and utility.

Appendix F Comparison to q-FFL

In the scenario where we treat each client as a different group, our method reduces to a generalized version of AFL [27] where we allow the constraint term to encode different values of ζ𝜁\zeta. We compare our method with q-FFL [20], a popular method that encourages providing fair utility performance across all the clients. For fair comparison, we plot the average test accuracy w.r.t the largest client’s loss for both methods. Our method achieves comparable results with q-FFL in this setting, and both methods yield models that are both fairer and more accurate than vanilla FedAvg.
